title: How to get people to listen when I speak - Quora

response.answer_text: Say something worthy of being heard. I know a lot of people, teenagers especially, who feel like they are constantly being the Wallflowers of the social arena. Talking to people and being effective at communicating is exactly that—an arena. As an introverted person and a former member of the shy club, I know the frustration of not being heard. People would talk over me or even talk like I wasn’t there at all. Although it seems unfair and unjust, knowing the rules of communication are pertinent in a society of performers and expert players of the game we call life. That being said, you get heard by saying something worthy of being heard: Because of the content of the message.Because of the execution of the message.This past February I was mortified as I spent weeks preparing for an important chapel about achievement and success I had to give in front of my entire school. I practically had people rooting for my failure and expecting me to say something awkward or cringe worthy or a nice mixture of both. People expected me to fail. In an attempt to calm my nerves my best friend told me not to even care about what I would say due to the fact that mostly everyone fell asleep in chapel anyway. No way. Not anymore. Not to me! I completely threw away my plan and made a new one the night before. I typed everything out the next morning only mere hours before i stood in front of a crowd of 500 clueless teenagers and another 100 beaten down adults. The message started fairly slow with stories and bible verses that usually accommodated the average chapel, and right when I saw nearly all of the student body on the verge of a coma I said it, “I’m a SLUT for success” The students went crazy. Half the teachers wanted me dead. The other half were secretly amused. The more conservative faculty was ready to crucify me. Everyone was listening. I was able to know my audience and execute a graphic plan that got the whole school to pay attention to what I had to say. For the next ten minutes I was able to preach about the failure to reach perfectionism, mental health issues, and a Christian solution to our obsession with success. I painted a picture for the audience that showed the dangers of self pride and thenhelped them through their own fears of facing it. Depsite the memes, jokes, and even t-shirts made about my statement, I was able to be heard among my peers and, something even more important, people remembered what I had to say. People started going to the guidance counselors more. People thanked me for introducing them to crisis text lines. If you want to be heard, say something worthy of being heard. You have to work on communication skills just like you would any other athletic or educational skill. You can always do better. Keep striving for greatness, just don’t be a slut for success as you go on your way. TL; DR- say something worthy of being said by making your execution interesting so people can also pay atesnrjon to your interesting content. I shocked my Lutheran High School by making leud sexual metaphors during a chapel and everyone was all the better for it.

Um.. question - Why do you want to get people to listen to you ? - If it’s all about being accepted by them, don’t do it. It will not add any long term value to your life. If you are looking to grow as a people person(career(leadership)/interest) - you have to observer behavior of people and (hence) be in sync with them, Most people don’t like content, however how it looks(don’t believe me - why do girls/actress wear makeup ? :D) , you have to tolerate and take/accept a lot of things that you consider plain ‘stupid’ and at times act like one as well - This will take toll on you in case you are an introvert. Now that you have observed people’s behavior - what offends them, present yourself in a fashion that they like/prefer. - They will initially start liking you. Later with interaction you can build rappo - and start expressing yourself. You can also exhibit and display a unique behavior however - they may or may not like it(every startup does not becomes apple :), although apple target is not the whole world however a small set of consumers who are ready to pay high for better quality(everyone in the world is not big fan of Quality in smart phones) ) After doing all that over a period of time - you will still find people who don’t like/hear you. Hence - Do what you feel is ‘right’ not what people ‘like’. Identify and them focus on your goals and keep working on them instead of getting people to like you. When you present yourself - you attract people who like you for what you are - you don’t have to fake anything with these people and these are the people who will hear you in all situations. If you present yourself as you are - you will attract ‘permanent’ people in your life who will stay with you in longer run - since you don’t change - they don’t leave you. If you are genuinely looking to change - display (fake it untill you make it) the changed behavior - You will attract like-minded people - their company will help you change. ( that’s why you should only do this if you are looking to change)

Very easy, seriously, very easy.. Are you talking to your colleagues at work? Workshop? Seminar? Or any public speaking event? You may see many articles on Google about ‘ effective communication key’ and all of them are very clear.  Figure: Illustration of communications (source from Google) But let me tell you what you can do to make people listen more, no matter you’re at work, public events, sharing to friends, or confide in someone. Here are some of my tips. Make sure your opponent is not wearing headphone. It’s useless if you try talking to them even they turning off what they just listening to. Come on, if they don’t listen to you, you may get hurt, though the fact is you are the one that cannot see your environment. There are many reasons why people don’t unwear headphone when you come. Maybe they just lazy to put it off or they really avoid you. But take it easy, just don’t talk to them.See if people are busy or free. You cannot ask someone to stop their work just to focussing themselves on you. They may looking at you, nodding their head, hearing your voice, but you will easily notice that they are not listening to you. So better if you already know someone or people get busy, just let it go. See if people are prepared to listen, similar with point number 1.Make a good greeting and tell people what’s your purpose. Ask how people are doing, like you usually do. If you see the point number 2 and you found that people are ready to focused on you, then go! Then, let them know what you gonna tell them to see are they interested in or not. You will notice people’s gesture just in few seconds.If people interested to listen, then communicate with a clear plot, be systematically. As I always try, I never make a plot twisted, like go ahead then go back, no no no, that’s really bad. People need to know whole story to keep the ideas on their mind. Like you construct a building, you have to do it systematically from bottom to the top, from the base one to the complex one. Oh yeah, i almost forgot, avoid the gap on your talking, like sounds “eeemmm.. uuuhhh.. aaaaa..” when you’re thinking. People will get bored if you did it.Stay smooth and don’t be emotional. You may get mad, happy, sad, or anything, but always try to be constant in everything. Stabilize you emotions, don’t nervous, adjust your voice, make people relax. People will connected automatically to you if you bring the ‘safe’ image of you. Be calm and be nice..Attention to your body language. Similar with point number 5, you have to do it to your body too. Let your body language open and you can see how people are comfortable on facing you. Sit well or stand up well, don’t be a robot, keep flexible.Be honest, don’t manipulate. You tell what you are going to tell, not more. You may expected someone’s reply, so you make a story complicated. It’s not a good way because you will not get what people think and they will know you’re lying or hiding something.Talk with heart and eyes. This is the core of the core, hahaha.. The key of communication is you send your message to people’s heart and mind, not just to their ear. Look at them, be aware of your sight and keep your heart stays feel. It’s different with being emotional, stays feel means your heart is deeply opening and you are ready to transfer it to your opponent. It’s like you transfer an energy, sympathy, and empathy to someone. If you can feel, make your eyes warm, connected to your heart, because eyes are the windows.If you just do every point on number 1 to 8 and people still not listening to you, just go away and let it go. There are some people who never care about someone. Don’t blame them, don’t blame yourself. They are just not ready about the things you will tell, and you don’t need the reason why.Nice to answer, hope this will help you.. ^_^

The art of discourse.  The first rule of any communication is to deliver value for time donated to listening. A comedian will make us laugh, we know this and so we listen. There is a fit. we gain value in doing so. A lecturer in a university can spend hours talking on one subject and his students listen intently because for them there is value. They learn. There is a fit. So why do people invest their time to listen? The answer is trust. They already know what to expect from the speaker. They understand from experience that time invested here will yield reliable results. They trust they will gain value. The speakers have reputation. Reputation When we experience one another in the human tribe we become aware of patterns of behaviour. If we encounter an individual who brings us little value because they talk aimlessly on subjects we have no interest in then after once or twice of bumping into them, we learn to avoid them. The next time we see them we will employ whatever avoidance tactic we are comfortable with. We may state we are running late, we might abruptly give attention to someone or something else and move on impolitely, or we might simply go a different way on sight of them! We may adopt to miss their call. We do this because the person we are encountering has a low reputation with us. There is no value, in fact we gain nothing and we lose our time. We feel stress as we grow impatiently trapped in their grammar bubble! We tend to invest time and listen most to people we gain value from in one way or another. Value is the thing that makes a person acceptable to us. In moments of discourse value is created when the discourse delivered is appropriate, timed well and spoken considerately. Being appropriate In any given situation we can maximise the chance of becoming accepted and valued by making sure we are appropriate for that situation. This means checking three important things. Is our timing correct? If we attempt to speak at length to someone and misjudge that persons current priorities then we fail before we start.Is what we have to say going to bring immediate value? This could mean entertainment (humour, news, style of delivery), it might mean education (the delivery of instantly useful knowledge) It might mean emotional support (sympathy, understanding, encouragement)Do we have the qualification? Becoming too familiar with somebody we barely know before we are entitled is going to pressure the listener. For instance; if we begin to educate a person on a subject before they have accepted us as being qualified to do so. If we do not qualify for delivery we fail before we start. (There can be exceptions to this where perceptions of authority become involved)If we get number one wrong and misjudge timing, we become an inconvenience. If we get number two wrong and speak on a subject the person has no interest in, then; we become boring. If we get number three wrong and attempt a full on delivery of information without the person knowing us then; we become over familiar and unqualified. There are other mitigating factors that can further complicate an exchange but these three are without doubt very important basic factors. Reading a situation. All of the above amounts to reading the situation. If we respect the circumstances we find ourselves in with a person and respect our position in relation to that person then we can avoid falling on our face by communicating inappropriately. It is a wise approach to sit back, observe and calculate ones position before rushing in with a delivery. You cant talk about your new phone to a man putting the fire out in his house! Sharing the spotlight. Too often I come across people where conversation is all about them. This is a big mistake in any conversation! When we talk at length to someone all about our world, our thing or our situation, and we do not allow the other person to share their own situation, then the captive audience becomes an escapee very quickly. In order to develop a healthy conversation it is wise to be aware of how long we speak for. I try to keep my discourse down to a few sentences at most and then deliberately find a way to include my listener. I ask a question and invite them to participate. I am always interested in the other person. People like to share about themselves too! For this reason I try to share the spotlight! Know your strengths. Many people can optimise their reputation with others by understanding their own strengths. I often see insecure young people desperate to be accepted rush into a conversation with underdeveloped humour, loosely remembered non facts or inappropriate comments. Their insecurity gets mixed up with some fantasy image they have in their minds of the impressive person they wish they were. Often based on some role model that impressed them. In doing so they try to become a square peg in a round hole. Their personality doesn't fit, the way they look doesn't fit, their style of delivery is no where near developed enough and so they fall on their face and just come across as naive and rather silly. If they took time to understand their own true assets, that bring value to others, then they would be able to rely on a solid personality base that has a proven track record. If a person has had success making people laugh then humour is a strength. If a person has had a lot of success by delivering emotional support then this is a strength. If a person has people asking a lot of questions on one specific area of study then they are regarded as knowledgeable. This is a strength. When we operate to our known proven strengths and remain cool calm and collected the remainder of the time we are far more likely to develop a healthy reputation. People with a healthy reputation are more likely to be listened to and liked. Basil Simon Musical life coach Official web site

How do I get people to listen to me? I always have to listen to them; I feel unimportant. You have conjoined two issues in your question which I think should be viewed separately. The first is feeling unimportant; the second is getting people to listen to you. On feeling unimportant This could be the result of low self-confidence and/or low self-esteem. If you don’t know and trust your own worth, why would others value you or pay attention to you? You resent feeling ignored so that tells me you do have some sense of your own value. Build on it. Healthy self-esteem is grounded in a factual appraisal of your strengths, skills and accomplishments as these reflect the values that are central to your identity. If you don’t know what your values are, read this: What Are Your Values?: Deciding What's Most Important in Life Make a list of your good qualities, skills and accomplishments. If you’re feeling down about yourself, ask a friend to help you. Make a second list of areas where you need to build strength. Give yourself credit for your strengths and think about how you could leverage them. Pick something about yourself that is a source of pride and think about how you could showcase it or build on it to take that confidence into another area of your life. Start a gratitude journal. Everyday, record something you are grateful for and identify something about yourself that you like or makes you feel proud. Let that feeling of justified pride feed your self-confidence. On getting others to listen I am a quiet, soft-spoken introvert but when I (eventually) choose to say something, people usually listen. Why? Because I’m assertive about it and I get to the point. I expect them to listen and indicate that by making eye contact and continuing to speak in a determined fashion if others start talking over me. If they continue bulldozing me, I will say “Excuse me, I haven’t finished speaking.” and then I continue. Does this approach work with obnoxious ignorant people? Not always. It’s then I recall the advice to not throw your pearls before swine.

Here are some things to do when speaking to someone or an audience.  Be authoritative.  If you don't make it clear that you're the big dog at the moment, there will be an inclination to not pay respect and attention. When I was a senior in high school, I had these two teachers on the opposite ends of the spectrum. Dr. M was new, and a nice person, but he was too soft. Nobody took him seriously during class throughout the entire year. On the other hand, Mrs. B established a rigorous reputation there for years, and it became immediately clear to new students that she was the leader of the wolfpack, and that she wouldn't take any of their BS. You want Mrs. B's approach.  Ditch the monotone.  You can't captivate an audience if you speak like a robot. Vary the pitch of your voice. If you don't sound excited, how will your audience? Nobody likes monotone. Except maybe Siri.  Interesting stuff first, then the details.  It's basically the top-down approach to speaking, and our brains are more receptive to this. Plus, if you start with the application, then the accompanying details will make more sense, and thus become more interesting. People like the exciting stuff. Make sure they get it, rather than sleep or daydream until you finally decide to lay it down.   There's plenty more to be said here, but these three tips will get you considerably far. Also, practice in front of a mirror. Incorporate hand gestures and be sure to speak boldly and clearly. Radiate confidence and excitement when you're speaking. People like that.

OBSERVE YOUR SURROUNDINGS : it is very important for you to understand that where exactly you are at that moment. What is the momentum of the place. Is the environment ambivalent, joyous or sad. This will help your brain to generate ideas and prepare your talk.BE A GOOD LISTENER: this is the foremost important thing if you want people to listen to you. You should be listening to them first. No one likes a person who just keeps on interrupting in between. Let them complete and then give your view.WELL VERSED WITH THE TOPIC : you also need to fully prepared and be aware of the facts before you start. Because lack knowledge and interest makes others disinterested too. You should be firm about your stand, well versed with all the facts and important information.BECONFIDENT: when it comes to speaking, confidence is very important. No amount of knowledge will make any difference if you don’t put in front of other with confidence. People tend to listen to those who know what they are speaking and can assure that is what is true. And this can only be done with fluency and confidence.I hope this helps! If you have any other questions. Please feel free to ask. thank you!

Listen to them - It’s a human thing. It sounds like you are not feeling heard, because you feel that others aren’t listening to you.  One of the biggest lessons I have learnt in my brief 35 years is that when I feel like there is an absence of something, to offer it, give it, give that very thing, to others. That internal whinge about the things in my life that are missing, I’d offer them to someone else. The whinge, I like to replace with the word hinge, a pivot point that I can swing back on my own behaviour to put me in a position of positivity and abundance mindset. When I offer to listen to others, magic happens and almost instantly, I feel better, and within a short amount of time, the person and I are in deep, respectful conversation, or if not with them, I am reaping dividends from someone else. There’s a secret trick to Listening - do you want to know what it is ..? How to listen to someone, how to really Hear someone, how to feel heard … Offer this to someone. Do this - Listen to understand. At a company I once worked for, I work with tech teams that were outstanding at their craft - the cream of the crop. Some of these excellent professionals become managers, and I have found an interesting theme when they were assigned direct reports. Here is it. They couldn’t listen to people. Incredibly solutions focused and driven, it was difficult for some individuals just to sit and listen, to invest in the other person, through time, patience, and comradery. They simply were out of practice in the human side of things and were very outcome focused, missing the point that the very thing that someone has to share, is the blocker for the outcome they are seeking. I put together a conversation tool to help them. It went something like this: 1/ Establish connection, trust and build rapport. ”I had this experience …..” 2/ How’s it going, what’s on your mind? The goal here is to listen to understand and establish what the participants dominant thought pattern might be. 3/ What are you working towards right now? Understand their what, why and how. Get curious. Ask open questions and really mine for information. 4/ Critical Step - The Secret Sauce - Repeat back to the participant what they have told you. “It sounds like …. “”You think/feel that …””Because/so that/etc””Is that right…?” And repeat, repeat, repeat until you can accurately retell the participant what they have told you - accurately for them, not for you. 5/ Listen for inner dialogue … the “I think” and the “I feels” Ask open, clarifying questions, that allow the participant to open up further - they do the talking, you do the listening. In the case of this particular company, I encouraged them to look for recurring themes and look for telling language.

I believe there are several ways to do this. One is to ask questions. People are much more interested in talking about themselves and their opinions than in listening to others. Another way is to be a compelling conversationalist. This generally requires some combination of deep knowledge and understanding of a subject (but don’t overload your audience with details!), a good sense of humor, empathy and emotional expressiveness (think Bill Clinton’s speech at the Democratic convention), and sensitivity to the interests of your audience and to the rhythms of conversation (know when to hand over the podium to the other person — we’ve all known people who talk too much without so much as a pause to allow the other person to get a word in, interrupt, fail to look for signs that the other person is losing interest, etc. — and seem oblivious to what they’re doing).

As someone who has been at both extremes- from fainting on stage to successfully hosting the annual day as an Emcee at High school, I believe that my answer might be worth considering. What did I change? Well, I had to work on a number of ques. Body language- Research and experience indicate the same thing- minimise movements which are wasteful. For example, certain lectures don’t require any leg movement but only require hand gestures. In most cases, this rule should be religiously followed; move your hands when required, while minimising leg movement.Eye contact- At a priliminary start, try avoiding direct eye contact. The best way to look confident while not having to see what others decipher of you, is to stare at the forehead and continuously look around the room, revolving around the centre. Foreheads don’t reflect emotions; all other parts of the face do.Before starting- Breadth. This is called the breadth exercise. Here, right before going on stage, stand near a mirror, look at yourself and smile while doing Three sets of breadth in’s and out’s.Practice the speech near a mirror- A mirror is the thing which worked for me. Talk into the mirror and smile throughout the process. Trust me, it really helps.The smile quotient- Keep a light, accepting smile on your face in all non- serious cases. The crowd will relate more with you.Material- Make sure what you say makes sense.Avoid aaaaaas and uhmmmmmms. This distracts the audience, even if your material is good.Remember, a confident lie is better than a nervous truth. Play your cards accordingly.

It's appropriate to participate, even if you have to metaphorically carve out a path.  Make a clear statement, don't begin with um or uh or "If you want to know what I think well maybe it could be because..." because no one will wait for you to get to your point. Just come out with it.
